qas.question: One of the two standard acid-fast staining techniques is the Kinyoun stain; what's the other?
What color will acid-fast bacilli become when stained?
What's the term for bacillus that can be exposed to acidic solutions without losing their stains?
If a scientist didn't want to use an acid-fast staining technique, what type of microscopy could they use instead?
What is another name for an expectorated sample?
What removes all stains from MTB?
What is another name for the Kinyoun stain?

context: Using histological stains on expectorated samples from <a0_0>phlegm<a0_0/> (also called "<b5_0>sputum<b5_0/>"), scientists can identify MTB under a microscope. Since MTB retains certain stains even after being treated with <b6_0>acidic solution<b6_0/>, it is classified as an <a3_0>acid-fast<a3_0/> bacillus. The most common acid-fast staining techniques are the <a1_0><b7_0>Ziehl–Neelsen<b7_0/> stain<a1_0/> and the Kinyoun stain, which dye <b8_0>acid-fast bacilli<b8_0/> a <a2_0><b9_0>bright red<b9_0/><a2_0/> that stands out against a blue background. Auramine-rhodamine staining and <a4_0>fluorescence<a4_0/> microscopy are also used.
